rules.description: Use Markdown H1 headings.
Reference titles use a precise noun phrase.
Omit verbs, imperatives, and questions, such as `configure`, `using`, `how to`, or `what is`.
Aim for 25 to 60 characters; 80 characters maximum.
Lead the sentence with the lookup object.
examples: Bad: `Limits of the Logos Storage API`

rules.description: If necessary, use cue words to signal the content type: `reference`, `syntax`, or `commands`.
Avoid meta-descriptions, such as `list of`, `table of`, `overview of`, `description of`, or similar.
Capitalize only the first word and any proper nouns (sentence-style capitalization).
Do not use punctuation marks, such as colons, semicolons, or dashes.

sections.title: Subtitle

rules.description: Use a Markdown H4 for the subtitle placed right under the H1 title.
Write one sentence only with no links, lists, or inline formatting.
End the subtitle with a period.
Stay under 20 words in the subtitle.
Use neutral verbs that state the purpose or benefit and avoid persuasive language.
Add new value beyond the title and do not repeat or rephrase the H1.

examples: **Title**: *Logos Storage limits* / **Subtitle**: *Understand the limits and resource constraints that apply to Logos Storage.*
**Title**: *Logos Blockchain v2 protocol reference* / **Subtitle**: *Review the network parameters and consensus rules used in Logos Blockchain.*

sections.title: Access callout

rules.description: Omit the callout entirely if no permission or product constraints exist.
Place the access callout after the title and subtitle and before the introduction.
Use the `Note` callout style for the access callout.
Use label-led, scannable content without explanations in the access callout.
Include permissions such as software role or permission level if applicable.
Include product information such as product version or edition if applicable.
If multiple permissions or products apply, separate them with commas.
Do not include knowledge, skills, or required tools in the access callout.

examples: > **Note** > - **Permissions**: Node operators, Site operators > - **Product**: Logos Storage v1.4.0 or later

sections.title: Callouts

rules.description: Use callouts sparingly and avoid placing them consecutively.
Use at most one callout per section.
Keep each callout concise at no more than two short sentences and move longer content into the body under a heading.
Ensure the callout content is directly relevant to the nearby text.
Use the appropriate callout type: `Tip`, `Note`, `Important`, or `Caution`.
For the allowed callout types and when to use them, see the writing rules document.

examples: > **Note:** > > Keep container resources within the documented limits to avoid throttling.

rules.description: Write one or two 50- to 100-word paragraphs explaining the purpose and relevance of the reference article.
Provide context or background information to help readers understand the information.
Link only when it helps disambiguate or provide a deep dive and aim for no more than two links.
If the intro is long or complex, link to other supportive documents.
Avoid meta-descriptions, such as `The following table [...]`, `This article includes the list of [...]`, or similar.
Treat the intro section as guidance only and do not render a visible heading or body for it.
Break down long lists or tables into smaller, more manageable sections using H2 headings.
examples: Use different lists or tables for different categories, like `Configuration`, `Authentication`, or `Networking`.

rules.description: Use one heading for one concept and do not mix two concepts under the same heading.
Arrange H2 sections from general to specific or from most important to least important.
Start an H2 section with a paragraph before adding lists or tables.
Refer to the list of common titles for H2 and H3 headings when choosing heading text.
examples: Headings: `Overview` / `Description` / `Purpose` — Use for: Brief definition + when/why to use it
Headings: `Usage` / `Synopsis` / `Syntax` — Use for: Command or short config example with required/optional parts
Headings: `Options` / `Flags` / `Parameters` / `Arguments` — Use for: Options/parameters with purpose, accepted values, defaults
Headings: `Examples` / `Example usage` — Use for: Runnable examples of common tasks
Headings: `Return values` / `Output` / `Exit codes` — Use for: Log lines or exit codes and their meaning
Headings: `Errors` / `Troubleshooting` — Use for: Typical errors, causes, and concise fixes

rules.description: Use tables or lists primarily to present reference data in H2 sections.
Ensure that any screenshots in H2 sections have non-empty alt text.
Follow the screenshot formatting rules in the writing rules document for H2 sections.
If code is present in an H2 section, use a fenced code block.
Keep code snippets in H2 sections short and illustrative.
Follow the code formatting rules in the writing rules document for H2 sections.
Nest H3 sections under the preceding H2 section and do not create orphan H3 headings.
If you add an H3 heading, ensure at least one sibling H3 follows or the split is unnecessary.
Use tables or lists primarily to present reference data in H3 sections.
Write a brief first sentence or paragraph with a description of the content before lists or tables in H3 sections.
Ensure that any screenshots in H3 sections have non-empty alt text.
Follow the screenshot formatting rules in the writing rules document for H3 sections.
If code is present in an H3 section, use a fenced code block.
Keep code snippets in H3 sections short and illustrative.
Follow the code formatting rules in the writing rules document for H3 sections.
Treat the extra guidelines section as guidance only and do not render a visible heading or body for it.
Keep narrative text concise, aiming for 400–900 words, excluding tables and parameter lists.
Do not use H4–H6 headings.
Do not include a "Further reading" section or links to other related topics at the end of the document.
